Description: Egyptian terracotta figure, fragment of man's midrift. A fragment from a large-scale male figure, perhaps a deity, surviving from waist to knee. He is draped from the belly down in a himation, with a roll at the top edge held up at the left by his lost left hand. There is no back to the figure. Hand modelled; the drapery is indicated with deep incision. Skin of the belly has a dark pink slip. Orange clay with a reddish core, abundant fine mica and some white inclusions: possibly not of Egyptian origin.
Curator's comments: Einer Gjerstad suggests that it is a Cypriot import of the end of the 5th or the beginning of the 4th century BC (Gjerstad 1948, 321), however Bailey publishes this in 'Ptolemaic and Roman Terracottas from Egypt' as of Late Period or Ptolemaic date (Bailey 2008, 152). This is confirmed by chemical analysis that places this within Egyptian marl clay fabric group. Gjerstad, E. 1948. The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV, Part 2: The Cypro-Geometric, Cypro-Archaic and Cypro-Classical periods. Stockholm, The Swedish Cyprus Expedition.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (C606)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.255) (Phase 1)
